page.title: 02Local History of Area
page.content: The names Saxilby and Ingleby are of Danish origin. At Saxilby, a Dane called Saxulf probably settled by marshy land near the Fossdyke canal (Roman created) close to an existing Anglo-Saxon settlement. Ingleby means settlement of the English and is mentioned in the original Domesday Book. Broxholme is also mentioned and means holme or island by the brook, brook being the River Till. Evidence of wide and deep ridge and furrow cultivation can still be seen in grassland at Broxholme and there are boundary ditches of some crofts and tofts along the medieval main street which fell into decay by 1840. One 17th century cottage remains. Ingleby also has evidence in the grassland of its historic lost village and has now amalgamated with Saxilby to form one parish.
